DeregistrationReasonOtherText: Facility was assigned 2 FAC_IDs Instructed to deregister the higher number

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary

UAP Distribution, Inc.
1506 West Wall Street
Harrisonville, MO

Updated 2/27/2007 to provide revised corporation information, as well as to include new required RMP information.  UAP Distribution, Inc., is the owner of this facility.  This facility was purchased from Old Mill Grain and Seed Company and formerly known as Old Mill Grain and Seed Company.

For more information regarding this plan, contact Dale Buxman, ERS Area Manager, 5701 Eureka Bend, McKinney, TX 75070 (972) 489-3154, or; Ron Osgood, Location Manager, UAP Distribution, Inc., 1506 West Wall Street, Harrisonville, MO. (816) 380-7449.

Risk Management Plan - Executive Summary

1. The Facility Policy

a) The owners, management and employees of UAP Distribution, Inc. are committed to the prevention of accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia.  If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the local fire department and other authorities to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment.

2. Facility Information

A) This facility is owned and operated by UAP Distribition, Inc., 

B) The primary activity of this facility, as it relates to anhydrous ammonia, is as a crop nutrient.

C) The maximum quantity of anhydrous ammonia stored in the largest tank is approximately 46,750 pounds.  This represents filling the storage tank to 85% of capacity as limited by design standards.

3. The Worst-Case and Alternate-Case Release Scenarios

A) The worst-case scenario is based on the entire contents of the storage tank being released over a 10 minute period.  The quantity released would equal approximately 46,750 pounds of anhydrous ammonia, which represents the volume of the largest tank filled to 85% capacacity as limited by design standards.  The distance to the endpoint (point of dispersion at 200 ppm) is 1.7 miles.

B) The alternate-case scenario is based on a release caused by a break in a transfer hose.  The quantity rel

ease would be approximately 26,640 pounds.  The distance to the endpoint (point of dispersion at 200 ppm) is 1.6 miles.

4. The Accidental Release Prevention Program

A) This facility has implemented the provisions of ANSI publication K-61.1, "Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia".

B) This facility is in compliance with OSHA Standard 29 CFR 1910.111, "Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia".

C) This facility follows the Anhydrous Ammonia Standards enforced by the Missouri Department of Agriculture, and is inspected by them on a regular basis.

D) The facility is inspected on at least a monthly basis by employees knowledgable in the safe handling of anhydrous ammonia.

5. The Five-Year Accident History

A) There have been no accidents in the previous five years involving the release of anhydrous ammonia at this facility.

6. The Emergency Response Program

A) This facility has an emergency response plan in accordance with OSHA Standard 29 CFR 1910.38.

B) This facility has provided State and Local Agencies the Emergency Planning and Community Right-To-Know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA).

C) This facility has a written emergency response plan in accordance with OSHA Standard 29 CFR 1910.120, which includes pre-emergency planning and employee training.

7. Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Safety improvement is an on-going process at this facility.  Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the maintenance of safety conditions, as well as to evaluate employee safety training programs.  There are no specific anhydrous ammonia safety recommendations or improvements planned to be made at this time.
